org.openpnp.spi

Interface Definable<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of the Definable
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.EventListener, java.beans.PropertyChangeListener
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Abstract2DLocatable, Board, BoardLocation, Panel, PanelLocation, Placement, PlacementsHolder, PlacementsHolderLocation, PseudoPlacement

    public interface Definable<T>
extends java.beans.PropertyChangeListener
    An interface used to indicate a one-way relationship of one object (the definition) to one or more other objects (the defined objects). Changes to the definition object flow to the defined objects but changes made locally to any of the defined objects do not affect the definition.

    Property setters are used to update the defined objects when the definition is changed, i.e., for a property defined as MyObjectType myObject;, the class should provide a setter method with a prototype of void setMyObject(MyObjectType newValue). This setter should set the property to the new value and then call firePropertyChange("myObject", oldvalue, newValue); to notify the property change listeners of the change.

    For some reason, Java Beans fails to recognize indexed property setters if they have the same name as the property and will entirely bypass the setter and just modify the element of the List or array directly. To work around this "feature", the index property setters must be named differently than the property. It is suggested that the names of indexed property setters use the singular version of the property name. For instance, suppose the property is defined as List<MyObjectType> myObjects;. In that case, the class should provide an indexed setter method with a prototype of void setMyObject(int index, MyObjectType newValue) (Important: note the use of the singular setMyObject rather than the plural setMyObjects). This setter should set the item at the specified index to the new value and then call fireIndexedPropertyChange("myObject", index, oldvalue, newValue); (again note the use of the singular "myObject" rather than the plural "myObjects") to notify the property change listeners of the change.

      • propertyChange

        default void propertyChange(java.beans.PropertyChangeEvent evt)
        This method is called when bound properties are changed. It updates the properties of all objects that are defined by this object. It also marks this object as being modified whenever one or more of its bound properties change value.
        Specified by:
        propertyChange in interface java.beans.PropertyChangeListener
